docs.lead_paragraph: In the month since the public release of the Surgeon General's report on the impact of television violence on children, a growing number of those involved have begun to air their misgivings about the report's accuracy in reflecting the research on which it was largely based.

headline.main: Study Aides Voice Misgivings About Report on TV Violence; Study Aides Score Report on TV Violence

docs.abstract: Growing number of researchers involved in US Surgeon Gen rept on TV violence are beginning to challenge rept's accuracy; harshest criticism comes from Drs M M Lefkowitz, J Murray, R Liebert and Repr J M Murphy; critics maintain rept tends to support TV indus position that children are not significantly affected by TV violence; contend evidence clearly contradicts rept's finding; Dr S Chaffee criticizes press's handling of rept; Dr I Rubinstein holds rept was misinterpreted because it was written in 'soc-science language'; says rept was compromise; Dr A E Siegel says com feared Govt moves toward control or censorship; Sen Pastore, at whose request study was undertaken, plans to hold public hearings to explore what he calls rept's ltd conclusion
